title: Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP)
icd10: F02.80 (Dementia in other diseases classified elsewhere
F02.81 (Dementia in other diseases classified elsewhere
scope: ** Diagnosis and comprehensive management of progressive supranuclear palsy in adults across ED, hospital, outpatient, and ICU settings. Covers MDS-PSP diagnostic criteria application, imaging workup, symptomatic pharmacotherapy (levodopa trial, symptomatic medications), fall prevention, dysphagia management, supportive care, and palliative care integration. Excludes other atypical parkinsonian syndromes (MSA, CBD, DLB) as primary diagnosis, drug-induced parkinsonism, and pediatric tauopathies.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline health; infection screen in falls workup
Electrolytes, hepatic/renal function for medication dosing
Hypothyroidism can cause slowness and gait dysfunction
Deficiency causes myelopathy and gait instability
Neurosyphilis in differential of vertical gaze palsy
UTI as cause of acute worsening, delirium

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Lyme disease in endemic areas (cranial neuropathy)
Paraneoplastic syndrome causing parkinsonism or gaze palsy
Whipple disease mimics PSP (oculomasticatory myorhythmia, gaze palsy)

Specialized Testing.rationale: Emerging biomarker; elevated in neurodegeneration; may correlate with disease severity
Familial PSP rare; MAPT H1/H1 haplotype is risk factor
Research biomarker; may help differentiate tauopathies

Essential/First-line.target: Midbrain atrophy ("hummingbird sign" on sagittal, "morning glory sign" on axial); midbrain-to-pons ratio decreased; third ventricle dilation

Extended.target: Midbrain area <70 mm2 on midsagittal; midbrain-to-pons ratio <0.52 (MRPI)
Reduced striatal uptake (abnormal in PSP, PD, MSA)
Frontal and midbrain hypometabolism; "frontal lobe syndrome" pattern

Extended.timing: Research; not yet validated for PSP specifically
Extended.target: 4R-tau deposition in basal ganglia, brainstem, cortex

Extended.timing: Distinguish PSP from PD (preserved in PSP, reduced in PD)

Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorder specialist for diagnosis confirmation, MDS-PSP criteria application, and ongoing management optimization
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, fall prevention strategies, and use of weighted walker
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, home safety evaluation, and assistive device fitting
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation (VFSS or FEES), dysarthria management, and communication strategies
Neuro-ophthalmology for evaluation of vertical gaze palsy, blepharospasm, and prism fitting for downgaze difficulty
Neuropsychology for baseline cognitive assessment and characterization of frontal-executive dysfunction
Psychiatry for depression, pseudobulbar affect, behavioral changes, and caregiver support
Social work for community resources, disability planning, caregiver respite, and long-term care planning
Palliative care for goals of care discussion, symptom management, and advance care planning early in disease course
Nutrition/Dietitian for caloric optimization, texture-modified diet guidance, and PEG tube nutrition planning
Pulmonology for respiratory function monitoring if respiratory compromise suspected
Orthopedic surgery or trauma consult for fracture management in fall-related injuries

Patient/Family Instructions.item: PSP is a progressive neurodegenerative disease; no cure exists but symptoms can be managed to improve quality of life
Falls are the most dangerous complication; use a weighted walker at all times when mobile to prevent backward falls
Do NOT attempt to walk without assistive device or supervision given high risk of serious falls and head injury
Return to ED immediately if fall with head injury, loss of consciousness, or new neurological symptoms (worsening speech, inability to swallow, breathing difficulty)
Swallowing will gradually worsen; follow speech therapy recommendations for diet texture modification to prevent aspiration pneumonia
Eat in upright position, take small bites, allow adequate time for meals, and avoid talking while eating to reduce choking risk
Levodopa trial may provide modest benefit; take medication with meals and report any improvement in movement to your neurologist
Do NOT stop any prescribed medications abruptly without physician guidance
Report pseudobulbar affect (involuntary crying or laughing) as this is treatable with medication
Establish healthcare proxy, power of attorney, and advance directives early while patient can participate in decision-making
Contact CurePSP (curepsp.org) and PSP Foundation for patient and caregiver support resources
Driving should be discontinued due to impaired downgaze, slowed saccades, and cognitive changes affecting reaction time

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Home safety evaluation: remove throw rugs, install grab bars in bathroom, improve lighting, eliminate trip hazards
Use weighted or rolling walker (weighted preferred to counteract backward falls tendency in PSP)
Wear hip protectors to reduce fracture risk from falls
Regular physical activity within safe limits: seated exercises, recumbent cycling, supervised balance training
Head-of-bed elevation to 30 degrees for orthostatic hypotension management and aspiration prevention
Maintain adequate hydration and nutrition; high-calorie supplementation if weight loss occurs
Cognitive stimulation activities (puzzles, reading, social engagement) to support remaining cognitive function
Avoid sedating medications (benzodiazepines, anticholinergics, antihistamines) that increase fall risk and cognitive impairment
Caregiver respite planning; caregiver burnout is common in PSP given rapid functional decline
Avoid excessive heat exposure which may worsen symptoms

differential.features: Asymmetric onset, rest tremor, excellent levodopa response, limb > axial rigidity, no early falls, no vertical gaze palsy
differential.tests: DaTscan (abnormal in both), MIBG (reduced in PD, normal in PSP), MRI (no midbrain atrophy in PD), levodopa trial

differential.features: Early severe autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary retention), cerebellar signs (MSA-C), stridor, poor levodopa response
differential.tests: MRI ("hot cross bun" sign, cerebellar atrophy), MIBG (preserved in MSA), autonomic testing

differential.features: Markedly asymmetric, limb apraxia, alien limb phenomenon, cortical sensory loss, myoclonus, dystonia
differential.tests: MRI (asymmetric cortical atrophy), FDG-PET (asymmetric cortical hypometabolism)

differential.features: Visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, REM sleep behavior disorder, dementia before or within 1 year of parkinsonism
Prominent personality/behavioral changes, disinhibition, apathy, compulsions; no early motor features
differential.tests: MRI (frontal/temporal atrophy), FDG-PET (frontal hypometabolism), neuropsychological testing

differential.features: Stepwise progression, lower-body predominant, vascular risk factors, gait disorder, no tremor
differential.tests: MRI (extensive white matter disease, lacunar infarcts), vascular risk factors

differential.features: Magnetic gait (feet glued to floor), urinary incontinence, dementia; triad
differential.tests: MRI (ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy), large volume LP tap test with gait improvement

differential.features: Oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pathognomonic), diarrhea, weight loss, arthralgias, vertical gaze palsy
differential.tests: PCR for Tropheryma whipplei (blood, CSF, small bowel biopsy); PAS-positive macrophages

differential.features: Vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, ataxia, dystonia; younger onset; organomegaly
differential.tests: Filipin staining of fibroblasts, NPC1/NPC2 genetic testing, oxysterol levels

differential.features: Rapid progression (weeks-months), myoclonus, cortical visual changes, MRI cortical ribboning
differential.tests: MRI (DWI cortical ribboning), EEG (periodic complexes), CSF RT-QuIC, 14-3-3 protein

differential.features: Temporal relationship to dopamine-blocking agents; symmetric; may include vertical gaze limitation with certain agents
differential.tests: Medication review; DaTscan (usually normal); improvement after drug withdrawal

evidence.recommendation: MDS-PSP diagnostic criteria
Levodopa trial recommended in PSP workup
Limited levodopa response in PSP (<30% of patients)
MRI midbrain atrophy (hummingbird sign) supports PSP diagnosis
Magnetic resonance parkinsonism index (MRPI) distinguishes PSP from PD
MIBG cardiac scintigraphy normal in PSP, reduced in PD
Amantadine may improve gait freezing in parkinsonian syndromes
Botulinum toxin effective for blepharospasm and dystonia
Botulinum toxin effective for sialorrhea in neurodegenerative disease
Dextromethorphan/quinidine (Nuedexta) FDA-approved for pseudobulbar affect

evidence.recommendation: Cholinesterase inhibitors for cognitive symptoms in PSP
Coenzyme Q10 failed to show efficacy in PSP
Riluzole failed to show benefit in PSP

evidence.recommendation: Davunetide failed phase II/III in PSP
Weighted walker superior to standard walker for PSP backward falls

evidence.recommendation: PSP-RS most common variant; median survival 6-9 years
PSP neuropathology: 4-repeat tauopathy with globose neurofibrillary tangles

Serum neurofilament light chain elevated in PSP

PSP clinical variants and tau pathology correlations
Physical therapy and exercise benefit in atypical parkinsonism

disposition.criteria: Most PSP patients; ambulatory (with assistive device), adequate home support, stable swallowing, no acute illness

Fall with serious injury (fracture, subdural hematoma, head injury); aspiration pneumonia; inability to maintain oral intake; acute delirium or rapid decline; UTI or other infection causing significant functional worsening
Acute condition treated; safe swallowing or PEG in place; ambulatory with assistance; caregiver education completed; outpatient follow-up arranged; home safety plan in place
Aspiration pneumonia with respiratory failure; severe sepsis from aspiration or UTI; post-fall with intracranial hemorrhage requiring monitoring; respiratory failure requiring ventilatory support
Unable to safely live at home despite maximum support; recurrent falls despite interventions; severe dysphagia requiring constant supervision; advanced cognitive impairment
End-stage PSP; bedbound; unable to communicate; recurrent aspiration; patient/family goals focused on comfort; estimated prognosis <6 months
Diagnostic uncertainty requiring specialized movement disorder evaluation; consideration for clinical trial enrollment; complex symptom management
